suggested_topics: the engineering of ancient Roman aqueducts
how mycelium networks share resources underground
the economics of food trucks in major cities
the role of smell in human memory formation

formats.name: micro_memoir
formats.instruction: Describe a single vivid memory in one sentence. Use sensory details and surprise. No context, just the moment.

formats.name: future_postcard
formats.instruction: Write a postcard from the future, as if you're sending it to the present. Imagine what changes and capture a mood. 2-3 sentences.

formats.name: hypothetical_lab
formats.instruction: Invent a scenario that could never happen, then reason through how it would play out step by step. Use playful logic. 150-220 words.

formats.name: soundtrack_suggestion
formats.instruction: Pair a song or music genre with a random everyday experience and explain why. 1 sentence about each, plus a quirky connection.

formats.name: comic_strip_script
formats.instruction: Write the script for a 3-panel comic on a real-life dilemma. Include dialogue and narration, plus punchline panel. 80-140 words.

formats.name: reverse_advice
formats.instruction: Share a piece of advice you wish someone had given you, but phrase it as 'What NOT to do.' 2-5 sentences, specific and honest.

formats.name: object_interview
formats.instruction: Imagine you interview an inanimate object about its daily life. Write the Q&A in 3 exchanges, making it humorous or insightful.

formats.name: deep_dive_exposé
formats.instruction: Reveal the hidden history or underbelly of something ordinary. Use investigative tone, surprising facts, and dramatic turns. 300-480 words.

formats.name: flash_theory
formats.instruction: Pitch your wildest theory about something mundane, as if it's a serious discovery. 60-95 words, logical or absurd, but convincing.

formats.name: found_letter
formats.instruction: Write a letter you wish you’d find in a library book — mysterious, motivational, or funny. 1 paragraph, tone is up to you.

title_styles: Write a title as a mysterious teaser: 'Something changed after I did X…'
Write a title as an instruction: 'If you ever try X, read this first'
Write a title as an overheard quote: 'Apparently, X is what happens when Y'
Write a poetic, metaphorical title: 'The Day My Thoughts Became Paper Boats'
Write a title that hints at a secret: 'Hidden Misconceptions About X Revealed'
structure_variants: Structure as a three-part interview: question, response, twist.
Write as an annotated recipe — but for experiences, not food.
Frame as a series of diary entries over a week.
Write as if you’re an impatient narrator, jumping between thoughts with abrupt transitions.
Use a timeline format to walk through events chronologically, minute-by-minute or year-by-year.
topic_angles: Explore an everyday technology from the perspective of a beginner and expert.
Reveal the bizarre rituals people invent for productivity.
Dissect the strangest advice you’ve ever gotten (use stories or theory).
Trace the evolution of self-care from ancient times to today.
Investigate how color influences unexpected moments in daily life.
